question: Will Argentina's Chamber of Deputies impeach President Javier Milei before April 1, 2025?
description:
On 14 February 2025, the Panamanian company KIP Protocol created the [\$LIBRA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%24Libra) token, as part of a project called [*Viva La Libertad*](https://www.vivalalibertadproject.com/es-ar). The token launch was not publicised by the company, but a few minutes after its creation Argentina's President [Javier Milei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javier_Milei "Javier Milei") published on his official Instagram, Twitter and Facebook accounts, promoting it.

![](https://metaculus-web-media.s3.amazonaws.com/user_uploaded/0h9ZcPTAhdLnYSEVW.jpg.webp)

\[Translation:

Liberal Argentina is growing!!!
This private project will be dedicated to promoting the growth of the Argentine economy by funding small businesses and Argentine entrepreneurs.
The world wants to invest in Argentina.

vivalalibertadproject.com

Contract: Bo9jh3wsmcC2AjakLWzNmKJ3SgtZmXEcSaW7L2FAvUsU

\$LIBRA

LONG LIVE FREEDOM, DAMN IT...!!!]

The value of the token surged to \$5.20 and plummeted shortly thereafter, the price plummeted, resulting in approximately \$87 million in losses for around 74,000 investors.

Milei then posted [the following tweet](https://x.com/JMilei/status/1890606683291779195) (translated):

> A few hours ago I posted a tweet, as I have so many other times, supporting a supposed private enterprise with which I obviously have no connection whatsoever.
> ‎
> I was not aware of the details of the project and after having become aware of it I decided not to continue spreading the word (that is why I deleted the tweet).
> ‎
> To the filthy rats of the political caste who want to take advantage of this situation to do harm, I want to say that every day they confirm how vile politicians are, and they increase our conviction to kick them in the ass.
> ‎
> VLLC!

A timeline of the events can be found [here](https://cenital.com/el-minuto-a-minuto-del-memecoin-que-promociono-milei/) (in Spanish).

Opposition members have accused Milei of a rug pull and [have claimed](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cp9x9j89evxo) that they will initiate impeachment proceedings. In Argentina, the [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentine_Chamber_of_Deputies) (lower house) has the sole power to initiate impeachment proceedings and must approve articles of impeachment by a two-thirds majority vote.
fine_print:
The outcome of the trial in the Senate is immaterial for the purposes of this question.

Please note that the English words *impeach, impeached* or *impeachment* are used for the Spanish word *el acusado* or *los acusados* as used in Article 59 of Argentina's constitution ([Spanish version](https://www.congreso.gob.ar/constitucionSeccion1Cap2.php), [English version](https://www.congreso.gob.ar/constitucionSeccion1Cap2_ingles.php))

**Milei Announces Opening of Congress Sessions for Saturday Night**
President Javier Milei has announced that the opening of the ordinary sessions of the Congress will take place on Saturday, March 1st at 9 PM. This move is seen as an attempt to secure a large audience through a prime-time television broadcast. Milei's speech is currently being written and is expected to reflect his first year in office. Unlike last year's opening, where the focus was on the 'inherited legacy', this year Milei plans to present a balance of his own management and introduce new legislative proposals for 2025. Santiago Caputo, Milei's advisor, is coordinating the details of the speech, generating expectations in the political circle. The event also poses a challenge for the Executive's relations with the Judiciary, as Milei is pushing for the presence of the full Supreme Court during the ceremony. However, this move has raised concerns, especially in the context of the controversy surrounding the nominations of judges Ariel Lijo and Manuel García Mansilla. Despite the setback in the Chamber of Deputies, where the officialism failed to gather the necessary votes for their designation, the Milei government has stated its intention to continue and nominate these figures by decree. This move has generated reservations and uncertainties, with warnings from the Palace of Tribunals about the risks associated with such decisions. The judges, who would still maintain their positions in the Judiciary, would face the uncertainty of resigning to accept new designations, a situation that presents significant personal and professional implications. The opening of sessions will not only be a platform for Javier Milei to reaffirm his leadership, but also a reflection of the current challenging political scenario in Argentina, forcing the president to rethink his strategy in a game of politics where the standard rules are suspended.

**Milei to Deliver Speech on 'Cultural Battle' at Congress Opening**
Argentine President Javier Milei is set to deliver a speech at the opening of Congress on Saturday, which will focus on 'deepening the cultural battle'. Milei will be accompanied by Senate President Victoria Villarruel and House of Deputies President Martín Menem. The speech is expected to last around 35 minutes and will emphasize the importance of the 'battle cultural' and the need for a 'reconstruction of the country'. Milei will also highlight the results of his economic management, including low inflation and fiscal adjustment. The government has invited Ariel Lijo and Manuel García Mansilla, two lawyers recently appointed to the Supreme Court, to attend the speech. This move has increased tension in the opposition, who have criticized the appointments by decree. The speech comes at a time of fragmentation among opposition blocs, which the government is seeking to exploit. Milei's speech will also address the recent requests for impeachment proceedings against him related to the Libragate scandal. Additionally, the opposition is still demanding that the government revisit the 2025 Budget. In his previous speech, Milei spoke for 43 minutes and accused lawmakers of being part of a 'caste' that has enriched themselves at the expense of the poor. He also announced a megaproject to eliminate the privileges of politicians and their friends, but most of these initiatives have not been successful in Congress.

**Convocan sesión especial para investigar a Milei por la cripto Libra**
A special session has been called in the Chamber of Deputies to investigate President Javier Milei over the Libra cryptocurrency scandal. The request, presented by the Democracia para Siempre block, has the support of other opposition parties. The investigation will include the interrogation of key government officials, including President Milei, his sister and Secretary General of the Presidency, Karina Milei, and the Minister of Justice, Mariano Cúneo Libarona. According to the block, it is the responsibility of the Legislative Power to oversee government actions, especially when they are involved in major controversies. The session is scheduled for March 11 at 12:00 and will include all recent projects related to the scandal, except for those that call for Milei's impeachment, which they consider too drastic at this stage of the investigation. Various political sectors have supported the initiative, including legislators from Encuentro Federal. However, the main challenge for the opposition is that the projects lack a report, which means that they will require a special majority of two-thirds to be approved in a special session. To overcome this obstacle, the opposition blocks are considering requesting the emplacement of the relevant committees to report on the initiatives before the debate in the plenary.

**Argentina's 2025 Legislative Elections: A Crucial Test for President Milei's Government**
The 2025 Argentine legislative elections will determine the stability and future of President Javier Milei's government. The elections will also reconfigure the traditional political forces in the country. The results will have a significant impact on the country's alignment with the new global right-wing and the path it will take in the face of the new world order. President Milei has already begun 2025 by withdrawing Argentina from the WHO, praising Trump's policies, threatening to leave the Paris Agreement, declaring war on 'woke ideology', meeting with Musk, and promoting a fraudulent cryptocurrency that has led to lawsuits and impeachment requests. The elections will be a key test for the government's ability to implement its promised structural reforms, such as the privatization of public companies like Correo Argentino and Aerolíneas Argentinas. The opposition, on the other hand, aims to consolidate a majority to block these decrees and reverse some already challenged in court, such as the labor reform or the privatization of clubs. The outcome of the elections will have significant implications for the future aspirations of the candidates, with a good result potentially strengthening the government's ability to implement reforms and expand its territorial influence.

**Argentine President Javier Milei Impeached in Cryptocurrency Scandal**
Argentine President Javier Milei has been formally charged by prosecutor Eduardo Taiano in the case known as 'criptogate', which investigates his alleged involvement in the scandal surrounding the cryptocurrency $LIBRA. The investigation also targets several of Milei's advisors and business associates related to the cryptocurrency, whose meteoric rise and subsequent collapse caused massive financial losses. The charges against Milei include abuse of authority, influence peddling, fraud, and bribery. The case began when Milei publicly promoted $LIBRA on social media, causing a sudden surge in its value, only to plummet hours later, devastating over 40,000 investors. Suspicions suggest that government insiders may have engaged in insider trading, benefiting a small group of electronic wallets that withdrew nearly $100 million before the collapse. Those implicated in the case include Hayden Mark Davis and Julian Peh, international promoters of $LIBRA, as well as Mauricio Gaspar Novelli and Manuel Terrones Godoy, organizers of the Tech Forum 2024 event, where the link with the president allegedly emerged. Sergio Daniel Morales, an advisor to the Comisión Nacional de Valores (CNV) director, has been accused of potential conflicts of interest. Juan Grabois, one of the accusers, urged the investigation to proceed quickly, stating, 'For national dignity, Justice must act quickly.' The prosecutor has requested information from the Banco Central, CNV, and other financial institutions to track suspicious transactions and determine if there was a coordinated scheme of fraud orchestrated by Milei's inner circle.

**Argentina: Opposition Proposes Impeachment of President Javier Milei**
Members of the opposition party 'Union for the Nation' in Argentina have proposed a motion to the Argentine Congress to impeach President Javier Milei due to his promotion of a cryptocurrency scheme on social media. According to a document published by the party's bloc in the Chamber of Deputies on X, the motion aims to initiate constitutional impeachment proceedings against Milei, citing 'events that constitute grounds for political responsibility for his unsatisfactory performance of his duties.' The lawmakers accused Milei of performing his duties in an unsatisfactory manner and of abusing his powers. They also did not rule out the possibility of considering the president's actions as criminal offenses that require a court investigation. The lawmakers pointed out that, as an economist by education, and given his connections with the people who organized the project, Milei should have known that this was a scam. Before the motion can be considered by the parliamentary chamber, it must be approved by a parliamentary committee. To force the president to leave his position, the 'Union for the Nation' will need the support of the moderate opposition, which currently opposes the accountability process. Milei had published information on February 14 about a project aimed at helping small businesses in Argentina attract investment using cryptocurrencies. After a wave of criticism on social media, the president deleted the post, saying he was not aware of the project's details. However, a statement from the presidential office published on February 15 said that Milei had met with people related to the project at least twice to discuss it. After the president's initial post, the value of the cryptocurrency used in the project rose to $5 and then dropped to less than $1. A small group of cryptocurrency holders were able to make millions of dollars from the surge. After the report was published, the opposition began to accuse the president of committing crimes, including negligence, money laundering, and engaging in activities that do not align with the duties of a public official.

**Argentina's Opposition Seeks to Impeach President Milei Over Cryptocurrency Scandal**
Opposition parties in Argentina have presented separate bills to initiate impeachment proceedings against President Javier Milei for his involvement in the launch of the cryptocurrency Libra, which caused significant financial losses for thousands of people. The impeachment process is a constitutional mechanism that allows the National Congress to investigate the political responsibilities of high-ranking officials for possible crimes committed in office. The process involves the formation of a 31-member commission, the declaration of admissibility of the charges, and a vote in the Chamber of Deputies. If the charges are approved, the case will be sent to the Senate, where the president will be tried and potentially removed from office. This is the first time in recent history that impeachment proceedings have been initiated against a president in Argentina.

**Adorni: The $Libra case 'does not harm the Government'**
Manuel Adorni, the presidential spokesperson, stated that the case of the cryptocurrency $Libra 'does not harm the Government' and warned that those from the opposition 'will not be able to take advantage' because 'there is no crime' for the Government. Adorni emphasized that the Government sees no wrongdoing in President Javier Milei's promotion of $Libra and highlighted that these operations are 'classic' in Argentine politics. He also criticized the kirchnerismo, whose parliamentary bloc in the Chamber of Deputies announced yesterday that it will push for a impeachment trial, calling them 'a group of delinquents' and 'sinvergüenzas'. Adorni stated that the opposition does not understand what happened in the 2023 elections, as 'the people do not want them anymore, they detest them'. He also accused the kirchnerismo of being part of 'the helicopter club', seeking an early exit for Milei from the Presidency. Adorni confidently stated that 'that will not happen' and advised them to 'keep playing with the impeachment trial and the helicopter, because the President's honesty is unshakeable'. He emphasized that the image of Milei before the public opinion has not changed 'at all', and that this is because 'people look at the low inflation rate, the growing economy, the stable dollar, and a Government without corruption'. When asked about the possibility of a successful impeachment trial, Adorni replied that 'that will not happen' and recommended that they 'keep playing with the impeachment trial and the helicopter, because the President's honesty is unshakeable'.

**Argentine President Javier Milei Faces Impeachment Over Massive Cryptocurrency Scam**
Argentine President Javier Milei is facing a potential impeachment due to a massive cryptocurrency scam, known as $LIBRA, which he promoted on his social media platforms. The scam, which was launched in April 2024, promised investors a 50% return on investment for development in Argentina, but instead, it resulted in losses of over $4 billion for approximately 74,698 traders. The investigation, led by the US Department of Justice and the FBI, accuses Milei and other individuals of generating illicit gains of between $80 and $100 million through the scam. The President's sister, Karina Milei, is also implicated in the scandal, as she allegedly facilitated the access of two traders to the President's inner circle. Milei has denied any wrongdoing, stating that he only 'diffused' the information and did not promote the scam. However, experts have pointed out that the President's public promotion of the cryptocurrency, including including the contract address in his social media post, suggests a direct involvement. The Argentine Chamber of Deputies has initiated a process for a political trial against the President, and the Peronist coalition has filed a request for a impeachment trial.

**Argentina's President Milei Faces Impeachment Proceedings and Investigations**
Argentine President Javier Milei is facing multiple investigations and potential impeachment proceedings for alleged cryptocurrency fraud and other crimes. While Milei's team claims he was deceived and did not act quickly enough to remove the promotional message, lawmakers are pushing for a parliamentary inquiry and potential impeachment. The process will begin in the Chamber of Deputies and end in the Senate, requiring the support of two-thirds of both chambers to proceed. Some lawmakers, such as Esteban Paulón and Mónica Fein, have expressed concern over the gravity of the situation and called for the designation of authorities to investigate. The Coalición Cívica (CC) has requested the creation of an investigative commission, citing potential violations of the Law of Public Ethics and the Law of Financial Entities. Meanwhile, Unión por la Patria is pushing for a parliamentary impeachment, arguing that Milei's involvement in the alleged crime is of 'enormous gravity' and constitutes an 'unprecedented scandal'. The Frente de Izquierda is demanding that Milei provide explanations on national television, with Nicolás del Caño saying 'Will he face the music or hide like Minister Caputo?' The scandal erupted when Milei promoted the cryptocurrency $Libra on social media, which saw its value skyrocket from $0.0001 to $24.80 in just 20 minutes. The case has sparked intense debate, with some accusing the government of trying to victimize itself and others calling for Milei's resignation.

**Argentina's Congress to Consider Impeachment Motion Against President Javier Milei**
The Union for the Fatherland bloc in Argentina's Congress has announced plans to file a motion for impeachment against President Javier Milei, following a scandal over his promotion of a cryptocurrency on social media. The bloc claims that Milei's participation in a cryptocurrency scam is 'of enormous gravity' and 'a scandal without precedents.' However, the motion for impeachment faces a major obstacle: the Commission for Political Trial is currently without authorities due to an internal dispute within the Liberty Advances party. The Commission's president, Marcela Pagano, was voted out in April last year, and the current president of the Chamber, Martín Menem, has refused to recognize the new authorities. As a result, the motion for impeachment will have to pass through the Permanent Commission for Political Trial, which is currently without a president. The opposition parties, including the Coalition Civic and the Radical Disidents, have instead proposed the creation of an investigative commission to look into the matter. The outcome of the motion for impeachment is uncertain, and it is likely to face significant opposition in the Senate.

**Argentina's President Javier Milei Faces Impeachment over Cryptocurrency Scandal**
Four political leaders filed a criminal complaint against Argentine President Javier Milei on Sunday, accusing him of 'illicit association', 'fraud', and 'failure to perform public duties'. The complaint alleges that Milei promoted $LIBRA, a cryptocurrency with potential fraudulent ties, and was a key participant in a 'mega-fraud' that affected over 40,000 people, resulting in losses of over $4 billion. The complaint states that Milei was a 'necessary and fundamental' participant in the alleged scheme, which involved figures close to his circle, including Martín Menem, the president of the Chamber of Deputies. Additionally, lawmakers from Cristina Fernández's party and the Socialist Bloc have filed a motion to impeach Milei, but it is unlikely to succeed as it requires a special majority in Congress, which is unlikely to be achieved given the opposition from the Coalición Cívica and the PRO party of Mauricio Macri. As Cristina Fernández said, 'It is a serious situation that requires serious consequences.'

**Three Deputies Call for Impeachment of President Milei**
Three Argentine deputies, led by Esteban Paulon, have initiated a process to impeach President Milei over the LIBRA token scandal. The deputies, accompanied by Mónica Fein and Natalia de la Sota, aim to 'investigate and determine the responsibility of the president' in the alleged scam. According to the legislation, the Chamber of Deputies must gather a two-thirds majority to proceed with the impeachment process, which will then be judged by the Senate with the same majority. The goal of the process is to either remove or disable the president from office. The process begins with a vote to either dismiss or initiate the impeachment, which requires a simple majority of the members present. In 2023, a similar attempt to impeach members of the Supreme Court of Justice failed due to the lack of necessary majorities.

**Argentina's President Javier Milei Faces Potential Impeachment Process**
Javier Milei, the President of Argentina, is facing a potential impeachment process due to the scandal surrounding the cryptocurrency $LIBRA. The opposition is seeking to impeach him, with the Union for the Homeland party stating that 'Milei's participation in a crypto-related crime is of enormous gravity'. The Comisión de Juicio Político de Diputados, with 31 members, will evaluate the admissibility of the process. The impeachment process requires a two-thirds majority in both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate. Milei's government has been marked by conflicts with various sectors, and his viability in the face of an impeachment process depends on the composition of the Congress and the fragility of the alliances that support the officialism. 'Our block of national deputies decided to advance in the presentation of a request for impeachment against the President of the Nation,' explained the statement from the Union for the Homeland party. 'There is already a debate among the different blocks in Congress about whether there should be an investigative commission or if the impeachment is appropriate,' said Martín Losteau, president of the UCR. Maximiliano Ferraro, a deputy from the Coalición Cívica ARI, stated that Milei would have violated the Law of Public Ethics and the Law of Financial Entities, 'particularly in relation to advertising for the capture of resources (art. 19). The impeachment process is a constitutional mechanism by which the National Congress can remove the highest authorities of the country, including the President, the Vice President, the Chief of Staff, the National Ministers, and the judges of the Supreme Court. Its development depends on a complex political entanglement, in which legislative majorities are determinant.

**PRO and UCR Sector Unite to Protect President Milei from Impeachment**
The PRO and the official sector of the UCR, led by Rodrigo De Loredo, are trying to protect President Javier Milei from a potential impeachment. The opposition's swift action to investigate the crypto scandal in the Chamber of Deputies did not resonate with the PRO and the UCR sector. The common thread among the lawmakers closest to the government was to demolish the initiative to impeach Milei, which was pushed by the Unión por la Patria block. 'Those who ruined Argentina are asking for impeachment. 20 years of taking everything and now they're acting like moralists and republicans. They have no shame,' wrote Cristian Ritondo, president of the macrista bloc in the Chamber of Deputies. Patricia Bullrich, the Minister of Security, also claimed that there is no crime to justify a judicial and political attack on the head of state. Ritondo was not alone in his stance, as he was joined by his friend Diego Santilli, a close ally of the President and one of the two macrista leaders in Buenos Aires who are pushing for an electoral agreement with La Libertad Avanza in the province governed by Axel Kicillof. 'Thieves think everyone is like them. I'm sorry to say, but they're wrong. They'll be left with their desire to overthrow the President,' wrote Santilli. Guillermo Montenegro, the mayor of General Pueyrredón, also weighed in, drawing from his experience as a former federal judge. 'Now the irresponsible people who ruined the country are experts on Germán Bidart Campos and Elon Musk. To those who don't know the law, I say: nothing that happened constitutes a crime. They'll probably start asking for reports and calling officials just to get involved in the issue. Let them do what they want,' he replied. The radicals closest to the government, within the space led by De Loredo, are maintaining a strict silence and waiting for the official sector to take the lead. They have lowered the price for Martín Menem, the president of the Chamber of Deputies, and believe that the opposition needs to come to an agreement before they take any action. They also think that there will be no movement in the Chamber of Deputies until March 1st.

**President Milei's Agenda for 2025: Economy and International Relations**
Argentine President Javier Milei is starting his second year of governance focused on the economy and international agenda, before the country enters 'campaign mode' ahead of the 2025 legislative elections. Milei's international agenda has already led to his first major activity of the year, receiving and supporting the newly elected President of Venezuela, Edmundo González Urrutia, who is challenging Nicolás Maduro. Milei will continue to prioritize geopolitics, traveling to Washington D.C. on January 17 to attend Donald Trump's inauguration, where he will meet with Trump's team and business leaders. He will then head to Davos, Switzerland on January 21 to deliver a speech at the World Economic Forum, building on his strong message from last year's event, where he stated, 'Occidente está en peligro' ('The West is in danger'). This year, Milei's team expects another strong speech, saying, 'el mensaje del año pasado hizo mucho ruido y luego el mundo giró' ('the message last year made a lot of noise and then the world turned'). The President will also focus on the economy, aiming to maintain the country's financial and commercial surpluses, and a stable dollar, with the goal of eventually lifting the currency controls. This is expected to boost the ruling party's performance in the upcoming legislative elections, allowing them to strengthen their blocks in both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate.

**Milei Meets with Expelled Radical Deputies**
Javier Milei, the President of Argentina, met with 13 radical deputies, including Luis Picat, Mariano Campero, and Martín Arjol, who were expelled from the UCR party for collaborating with Milei's veto on laws related to mobility and university financing. The meeting, which lasted over two hours, took place at the Casa Rosada and was attended by other officials, including the Minister of Security, Patricia Bullrich, and the President of the Chamber of Deputies, Martín Menem. Milei confirmed that the government will send a new 'clean slate' project to prevent people with confirmed convictions from running in elections, following the failure of a previous project. According to Rodrigo de Loredo, the head of the UCR block in the Chamber of Deputies, Milei 'reiterated the will to send the project, despite what happened last month in parliament.' De Loredo denied that a possible electoral agreement for the 2025 legislative elections or the reform of the electoral system, including the elimination of the PASO primaries, was discussed during the meeting.
